results.content: This is the 3rd ngJS course I've taken on Udemy and it's the best one so far. The instructor starts by explaining concepts that form the foundation of the framework and he explains them well. Whereas in other courses instructors may say, "This is how you create a controller, and then this is how you use it, " Sandeep goes one step further and explains _why_ the code is structured the way it is. AngularJS is a hard framework (at least in my opinion) to master, and Sandeep makes using it a lot less intimidating. I did knock off half a star because he fast-forwards through his typing, making the course feel very rushed. I found myself rewinding and pausing more often in this course than in any other course I've taken. The other half a star was knocked off because the code in the Weather App module needs to be updated, as the API has since changed (I'm writing as of Sep. 14, 2016). I also wish there were more than one in-depth practice project. Nonetheless, if you want a course that explains concepts so that you understand them (not just know them) in a format reminiscent of Tony Alicea's "JavaScript: The Weird Parts," then this course is great for you!
results.content_html: This is the 3rd ngJS course I've taken on Udemy and it's the best one so far. The instructor starts by explaining concepts that form the foundation of the framework and he explains them well. Whereas in other courses instructors may say, "This is how you create a controller, and then this is how you use it, " Sandeep goes one step further and explains _why_ the code is structured the way it is. AngularJS is a hard framework (at least in my opinion) to master, and Sandeep makes using it a lot less intimidating. I did knock off half a star because he fast-forwards through his typing, making the course feel very rushed. I found myself rewinding and pausing more often in this course than in any other course I've taken. The other half a star was knocked off because the code in the Weather App module needs to be updated, as the API has since changed (I'm writing as of Sep. 14, 2016). I also wish there were more than one in-depth practice project. Nonetheless, if you want a course that explains concepts so that you understand them (not just know them) in a format reminiscent of Tony Alicea's "JavaScript: The Weird Parts," then this course is great for you!

results.content:
Good course. Very instructive videos. Clearly the instructor has put a lot of effort in the vids, by adding arrows, text boxes etcetra. 
Even for experienced developers there are things to be learned from this course. Would advice it.

In the last lesson you will create a complete weather forecast application. This is very, very instructive because you have to code along. Repeat: you have to code along. That is fantastic! Kudos to this teacher.

One tiny point of attention: the accompanying sources contain a few minor errors. But maybe solving those is just part of the fun!

results.content:
His presentation is poor, he also appears to be in a hurry to finish each topic or concept he's trying to explain. 

By the time he will get to the main project, the student would have forgotten most of the concepts talked about earlier.

I think a better approach would be something like this:

* introduce angular
* Introduce the project you intend to use in the course described with diagrams
* present the workflow of the app you are going to build in the project
* divide the app into modules and components
* use each new module/component to introduce and explain some concept
* show how this was implemented before Angular
* show how the concept is used and implemented in Angular
* talk about the advantages of the new approach vs the old
* build app to completion at a slow but steady speed

This way, the student carries along concepts introduced earlier further through hands-on practice, new concepts are introduced building on top of existing knowledge.
results.content_html:
His presentation is poor, he also appears to be in a hurry to finish each topic or concept he's trying to explain.

By the time he will get to the main project, the student would have forgotten most of the concepts talked about earlier.

I think a better approach would be something like this:

* introduce angular
* Introduce the project you intend to use in the course described with diagrams
* present the workflow of the app you are going to build in the project
* divide the app into modules and components
* use each new module/component to introduce and explain some concept
* show how this was implemented before Angular
* show how the concept is used and implemented in Angular
* talk about the advantages of the new approach vs the old
* build app to completion at a slow but steady speed

This way, the student carries along concepts introduced earlier further through hands-on practice, new concepts are introduced building on top of existing knowledge.

results.content: I took the Quickstart version of this course and really enjoyed it, so I came back for the Masterclass.  The instructor explained the concepts very well, and he worked through them at a comfortable pace.  I started getting a little lost towards the end, as he seemed to move through the last couple of sections pretty quickly, so I probably need to go back and re-watch those portions.  However, I did enjoy having a project to work on that brought all of the concepts into play.  Overall, very satisfied with this course!
results.content_html: I took the Quickstart version of this course and really enjoyed it, so I came back for the Masterclass. The instructor explained the concepts very well, and he worked through them at a comfortable pace. I started getting a little lost towards the end, as he seemed to move through the last couple of sections pretty quickly, so I probably need to go back and re-watch those portions. However, I did enjoy having a project to work on that brought all of the concepts into play. Overall, very satisfied with this course!

results.content:
This is a good course overall.  Instructor teaches hard to understand concepts in a nice intuitive manner.

The issue I have is that I'm not seeing best practices as far as the use of controllerAs as compared to the use of $scope everywhere. The interesting thing is, he started out using Controller As and moved away from it.

Understanding $scope is a important concept and I don't begrudge the instructor in teaching it. However, there is good reason that Angular 2.0 removed it and you won't see it in my angularJS code unless I'm using $broadcast, $on, or $emit.

In the end, I thought the course was worth taking.
results.content_html:
This is a good course overall. Instructor teaches hard to understand concepts in a nice intuitive manner.

The issue I have is that I'm not seeing best practices as far as the use of controllerAs as compared to the use of $scope everywhere. The interesting thing is, he started out using Controller As and moved away from it.

Understanding $scope is a important concept and I don't begrudge the instructor in teaching it. However, there is good reason that Angular 2.0 removed it and you won't see it in my angularJS code unless I'm using $broadcast, $on, or $emit.

In the end, I thought the course was worth taking.

results.content:
For some strange reason the instructor has accelerated the typing of the code by about twice or slightly less.  This makes it impossible to see what he's doing and really just skipping over code. Its difficult to work in parallel.   He also fails to introduce modules (e.g) 8 and just starts from code that is not introduced.

Not sure why you can't work at work pace and explain things properly ....

The content is also not useful to real world projects in my opinion.

I would give this course a skip

results.content: Good explanations, software design concepts, and well thought out plan for this course.  However, he goes too fast sometimes which requires me to pause the video to type in the code.  His accent is kind of thick, but you get used to it after a couple videos.  There are some mismatches between the video, audio, and downloaded code, but nothing major.  Also, although he uses MS Visual Studio Express, I'm using JetBrains' WebStorm and can follow along just fine.
